Sensor Networks with Random Links: Topology Design for Distributed Consensus

Soummya Kar and José M. F. Moura∗ The authors are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA 15213 (e-mail: soummyak@andrew.cmu.edu, moura@ece.cmu.edu, ph: (412)268-6341, fax: (412)268-3890.)Work supported by the DARPA DSO Advanced Computing and Mathematics Program Integrated Sensing and Processing (ISP) Initiative under ARO grant # DAAD19-02-1-0180, by NSF under grants # ECS-0225449 and # CNS-0428404, and by an IBM Faculty Award.
Abstract

In a sensor network, in practice, the communication among sensors is subject to: (1) errors or failures at random times; (2) costs; and (3) constraints since sensors and networks operate under scarce resources, such as power, data rate, or communication. The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is usually a main factor in determining the probability of error (or of communication failure) in a link. These probabilities are then a proxy for the SNR under which the links operate. The paper studies the problem of designing the topology, i.e., assigning the probabilities of reliable communication among sensors (or of link failures) to maximize the rate of convergence of average consensus, when the link communication costs are taken into account, and there is an overall communication budget constraint. To consider this problem, we address a number of preliminary issues: (1) model the network as a random topology; (2) establish necessary and sufficient conditions for mean square sense (mss) and almost sure (a.s.) convergence of average consensus when network links fail; and, in particular, (3) show that a necessary and sufficient condition for both mss and a.s. convergence is for the algebraic connectivity of the mean graph describing the network topology to be strictly positive. With these results, we formulate topology design, subject to random link failures and to a communication cost constraint, as a constrained convex optimization problem to which we apply semidefinite programming techniques. We show by an extensive numerical study that the optimal design improves significantly the convergence speed of the consensus algorithm and can achieve the asymptotic performance of a non-random network at a fraction of the communication cost.

Key words: Sensor networks, topology, consensus, distributed decision, convergence, graph, Laplacian, spectral graph theory.

I Introduction

We consider the design of the optimal topology, i.e., the communication configuration of a sensor network that maximizes the convergence rate of average consensus. Average consensus is a distributed algorithm that has been considered by Tsitsiklis in his PhD thesis, [1], see also [2], found application recently in several areas, and is the subject of active research, e.g,, [3, 4, 5, 6].

This topology design for sensor networks has not received much attention in the literature. References [7] and [8] consider restrict it to classes of random graphs, in particular, small-world topologies. The more general question of designing the topology that maximizes the convergence rate, under a constraint on the number of network links, was considered in our previous work, [9, 10, 11], where we reduced to average consensus the problem of distributed inference in sensor networks; see also [12].

Realistic networks operate under stress: (1) noise and errors cause links to fail at random times; (2) communication among sensors entails a cost; and (3) scarcity of resources constrain sensors and networks operation. We model such a non-deterministic network topology as a random field. Specifically, we assume the following: 1) at each iteration of the consensus algorithm, a network link is active with some probability, referred to as link formation or utilization probability; 2) network links have different link formation probabilities; 3) links fail or are alive independently of each other; and 4) the link formation probabilities remain constant across iterations. Designing the network topology corresponds then to (1) fixing the probability, or fraction of time, each link is used, (2) knowing that communication among sensors may be cheap (e.g., sensors are geographically close), or expensive, and (3) recognizing that there is an overall budget constraint taxing the communication in the network.

The paper extends our preliminary convergence results, [13], on networks with random links. The recent paper [14] adopts a similar model and analyzes convergence properties using ergodicity of stochastic matrices. Consensus with a randomized network also relates to gossip algorithms, [15], where only a single pair of randomly selected sensors is allowed to communicate at each iteration, and the communication exchanged by the nodes is averaged. In our randomized consensus, we use multiple randomly selected links at each iteration and, in contradistinction with [15], we design the optimal topology, i.e., the optimal weight (not simple average) and the optimal probabilities of edge utilization, recognizing that communication entails costs, and that there is a communication cost constraint. Other recent work on evolving topologies includes [16] that considers continuous time consensus in networks with switching topologies and communication delays, and [17] that studies distributed consensus when the network is a complete graph with identical link failure probabilities on all links.

We outline the paper. Section II summarizes spectral graph theory concepts like the graph Laplacian L𝐿L and the graph algebraic connectivity λ2​(L)subscript𝜆2𝐿\lambda_{2}(L). The Section formulates the problem of distributed average consensus with random link failures. Sections III and IV derive necessary and sufficient conditions for convergence of the mean state, mss convergence, and a.s. convergence in terms of the average E​{λ2​(L)}Esubscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left\{\lambda_{2}\left(L\right)\right\} and in terms of λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right), where L¯=E​(L)¯𝐿E𝐿\overline{L}=\mbox{E}\left(L\right). Section V presents bounds on the mss convergence rate. Section VI addresses the topology design for random networks with communication cost constraints. We formulate a first version of the problem, the randomized distributed consensus with a communication cost constraint (RCCC), and then an alternate version, which we show is a convex constrained optimization problem, to which we apply semidefinite programming (SDP) techniques. Section VII studies the performance of the topologies found by solving numerically the SDP optimization. We show that these designs can improve significantly the convergence rate, for example, by a factor of 333, when compared to geometric networks (networks where sensors communicate with every other sensor within a fixed radius) and that they can achieve practically the (asymptotic) performance of a nonrandom network at a fraction, e.g., 50 %, of the communication cost per iteration. Section VIII concludes the paper.

II Distributed Average Consensus

Subsection II-A presents two network models: Model 1) Nonrandomtopology in paragraph II-A1; and Model 2) Randomtopology in paragraph II-A2.  Subsection II-B considers distributed average consensus with nonrandom topologies in Paragraph II-B1 and random topologies in Paragraph II-B2. We assume synchronous communication throughout.

II-A Nonrandom and Random Topologies

In a nonrandom topology, the communication channels stay available whenever the sensors need to communicate. This model is described in paragraph II-A1, where we recall basic concepts from graph theory. In many sensor network applications, it makes sense to consider that links among sensors may fail or become alive at random times. This models, for example, applications when the network uses an ARQ protocol and no acknowledgement packet is received within the protocol time window, in which case the transmitted packet is assumed to be dropped or lost. This is also the case, when the transmission is detected in error. The random topology introduced in paragraph II-A2 models these networks.

II-A1 Nonrandom topology

The nonrandom topology is defined by an undirected graph G=(V,ℰ)𝐺𝑉ℰG=(V,\mathcal{E}), where V𝑉V is the set of vertices that model the sensors and ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is the set of edges that model the communication channels. We refer to G𝐺G as the supergraph, ℰℰ\mathcal{E} as the superset of edges, and edges in ℰℰ\mathcal{E} as realizable edges or links. This terminology becomes better motivated when we consider the random topology in Subsection II-A2. The cardinalities of the sets |V|=N𝑉𝑁|V|=N and |ℰ|=Mℰ𝑀|\mathcal{E}|=M give the number of network sensors and the number of channels or links, respectively. For the complete graph G=(V,ℳ)𝐺𝑉ℳG=(V,\mathcal{M}), ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is the set of all possible N​(N−1)/2𝑁𝑁12N(N-1)/2 edges. In practice, we are interested in sparse graphs, i.e., M≪N​(N−1)/2much-less-than𝑀𝑁𝑁12M\ll N(N-1)/2. We label a node or vertex by an integer n𝑛n, where n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,...,N\}. Sensors n𝑛n and l𝑙l communicate if there is an edge (n,l)∈ℰ𝑛𝑙ℰ(n,l)\in\mathcal{E}. Since the graph is undirected, if n𝑛n communicates with l𝑙l, then l𝑙l communicates with n𝑛n. The graph is called simple if it is devoid of loops (self-edges) and multiple edges. It is connected if every vertex can be reached from any other vertex, which in network terms may require a routing protocol. The number dnsubscript𝑑𝑛d_{n} of edges connected to vertex n𝑛n is called the degree of the vertex. A graph is regular if every vertex has the same degree d𝑑d. Unless otherwise stated, we consider only simple, connected graphs.

Associated with the graph G𝐺G is its N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N adjacency matrix 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}

𝒜n​l={1if (n,l)∈ℰ0otherwisesubscript𝒜𝑛𝑙cases1if (n,l)∈ℰ0otherwise\mathcal{A}_{nl}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1&\mbox{if $(n,l)\in\mathcal{E}$}\\ 0&\mbox{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (1)

The neighborhood structure of the graph is defined by

∀1≤n≤N:Ωn={l∈V:(n,l)∈ℰ}:for-all1𝑛𝑁subscriptΩ𝑛conditional-set𝑙𝑉𝑛𝑙ℰ\forall 1\leq n\leq N:\>\>\Omega_{n}=\left\{l\in V:~{}(n,l)\in\mathcal{E}\right\} (2)

The degree of node n𝑛n is also the cardinality of its neighborhood set

∀1≤n≤N:dn=|Ωn|:for-all1𝑛𝑁subscriptd𝑛subscriptΩ𝑛\forall 1\leq n\leq N:\>\>\mbox{d}_{n}=|\Omega_{n}| (3)

Let 𝒟=diag​(d1,…,dN)𝒟diagsubscriptd1…subscriptd𝑁\mathcal{D}=\mbox{diag}(\mbox{d}_{1},...,\mbox{d}_{N}) be the degree matrix. The graph Laplacian matrix ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is defined as

ℒ=𝒟−𝒜ℒ𝒟𝒜\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{D}-\mathcal{A} (4)

The Laplacian ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is a symmetric positive-semidefinite matrix; hence, all its eigenvalues are non-negative. We order the Laplacian eigenvalues as

0=λ1​(ℒ)≤λ2​(ℒ)≤⋯≤λN​(ℒ)0subscript𝜆1ℒsubscript𝜆2ℒ⋯subscript𝜆𝑁ℒ0=\lambda_{1}(\mathcal{L})\leq\lambda_{2}(\mathcal{L})\leq\cdots\leq\lambda_{N}(\mathcal{L}) (5)

The multiplicity of the zero eigenvalue of the Laplacian is equal to the number of connected components of the graph. Thus, for a connected graph, λ2​(ℒ)>0subscript𝜆2ℒ0\lambda_{2}(\mathcal{L})>0. In the literature, λ2​(ℒ)subscript𝜆2ℒ\lambda_{2}(\mathcal{L}) is referred to as the algebraic connectivity (or Fiedler value) of the network (see [18].) The normalized eigenvector 𝐮1​(ℒ)subscript𝐮1ℒ\mathbf{u}_{1}(\mathcal{L}) corresponding to the zero eigenvalue is the normalized vector of ones

𝐮1​(ℒ)=1N​𝟏=[1N​⋯​1N]Tsubscript𝐮1ℒ1𝑁1superscriptdelimited-[]1𝑁⋯1𝑁𝑇\mathbf{u}_{1}\left(\mathcal{L}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\mathbf{1}=\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\cdots\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right]^{T} (6)

For additional concepts from graph theory see  [19, 20, 21].

II-A2 Random Topology

We consider sensor networks where failures may occur at random due to noise as when packets are dropped. If a link fails at time i𝑖i, it can come back online at a later time (a failed transmission may be succeeded by a successful one.) We describe a graph model for this random topology. We start with the model in paragraph II-A1 of a simple, connected supergraph G=(V,ℰ)𝐺𝑉ℰG=\left(V,\mathcal{E}\right) with |V|=N𝑉𝑁|V|=N and |ℰ|=Mℰ𝑀|\mathcal{E}|=M. The superset of edges ℰℰ\mathcal{E} collects the realizable edges, i.e., the channels that are established directly among sensors in the network when all realizable links are online. These channels may fail at random times, but if (n,l)∉ℰ𝑛𝑙ℰ(n,l)\notin\mathcal{E} then sensors n𝑛n and l𝑙l do not communicate directly—of course, they still communicate by rerouting their messages through one of the paths connecting them in G𝐺G, since G𝐺G is connected. We now construct the model for the random topology problem, see also [13, 14, 15].

To model this network with random link failures, we assume that the state, failed or online, of each link (n,l)∈ℰ𝑛𝑙ℰ(n,l)\in\mathcal{E} over time i=1,⋯𝑖1⋯i=1,\cdots is a Bernoulli process with probability of formation Pn​lsubscript𝑃𝑛𝑙P_{nl}, i.e., the probability of failure at time i𝑖i is 1−Pn​l1subscript𝑃𝑛𝑙1-P_{nl}. We assume that for any realizable edges (n,l)≠(m,k)𝑛𝑙𝑚𝑘(n,l)\neq(m,k) the corresponding Bernoulli processes are statistically independent. Under this model, at each time i𝑖i, the the resulting topology is described by a graph G​(i)=(V,E​(i))𝐺𝑖𝑉𝐸𝑖G(i)=\left(V,E(i)\right). The edge set E​(i)𝐸𝑖E(i) and the adjacency matrix A​(i)𝐴𝑖A(i) are random, with E​(i)𝐸𝑖E(i) and E​(j)𝐸𝑗E(j), as well as A​(i)𝐴𝑖A(i) and A​(j)𝐴𝑗A(j), statistically independent, identically distributed (iid) for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. Note that E​(i)⊂ℰ𝐸𝑖ℰE(i)\subset\mathcal{E} and 𝟎⪯A​(i)⪯𝒜precedes-or-equals0𝐴𝑖precedes-or-equals𝒜\mathbf{0}\preceq A(i)\preceq\mathcal{A}, where 𝟎0\mathbf{0} is the N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N zero matrix and C⪯Dprecedes-or-equals𝐶𝐷C\preceq D stands for ∀1≤i,j≤N:Ci,j≤Di,j:formulae-sequencefor-all1𝑖𝑗𝑁subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗subscript𝐷𝑖𝑗\forall 1\leq i,j\leq N:C_{i,j}\leq D_{i,j}. We can think of the set E​(i)𝐸𝑖E(i) as an instantiation of a random binary valued M𝑀M-tuple. The probability of a particular instantiation E​(i)𝐸𝑖E(i) is Π(n,l)∈ℰ​Pn​lsubscriptΠ𝑛𝑙ℰsubscript𝑃𝑛𝑙\Pi_{(n,l)\in\mathcal{E}}P_{nl}. We collect the edge formation probabilities in the edge formation probability matrix

P=PT=[Pn​l],Pn,n=0formulae-sequence𝑃superscript𝑃𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝑃𝑛𝑙subscript𝑃𝑛𝑛0P=P^{T}=\left[P_{nl}\right],\>\>P_{n,n}=0

The diagonal elements are zero because the graph is simple (no loops). The structure of P𝑃P reflects the structure of the adjacency matrix 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} of the superset ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, i.e., Pn​l≠0subscript𝑃𝑛𝑙0P_{nl}\neq 0 if and only if 𝒜n​l=1subscript𝒜𝑛𝑙1\mathcal{A}_{nl}=1. The matrix P𝑃P is not stochastic; its elements are 0≤Pn​l≤10subscript𝑃𝑛𝑙10\leq P_{nl}\leq 1 but their row or column sums are not normalized to 111. Abusing notation, we will refer to P𝑃P as the probability distribution of the E​(i)𝐸𝑖E(i) and A​(i)𝐴𝑖A(i).

We now consider the average consensus algorithm for both nonrandom and random topologies.

II-B Average Consensus

We overview average consensus, see [1, 2] and also for recent work [3]. It computes by a distributed algorithm the average of xn​(0)subscript𝑥𝑛0x_{n}(0), n=1,⋯,N𝑛1⋯𝑁n=1,\cdots,N where xn​(0)subscript𝑥𝑛0x_{n}(0) is available at sensor n𝑛n. At time i𝑖i, each node exchanges its state xn​(i)subscript𝑥𝑛𝑖x_{n}(i), i=0,1,⋯𝑖01⋯i=0,1,\cdots synchronously with its neighbors specified by the graph edge neighborhood set, see eqn. (2). In vector form, the N𝑁N states xn​(i)subscript𝑥𝑛𝑖x_{n}(i) are collected in the state vector 𝐱​(i)∈ℝN×1𝐱𝑖superscriptℝ𝑁1\mathbf{x}(i)\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1}. Define the average r¯¯𝑟\overline{r} and the vector of averages 𝐱avgsubscript𝐱avg\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize avg}}

r¯¯𝑟\displaystyle\overline{r} =\displaystyle= 1N​𝟏T​𝐱​(0)1𝑁superscript1𝑇𝐱0\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\mathbf{1}^{T}\mathbf{x}(0) (7)
𝐱avgsubscript𝐱avg\displaystyle\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize avg}} =\displaystyle= r¯​𝟏¯𝑟1\displaystyle\overline{r}\mathbf{1} (8)
=\displaystyle= 1N​𝟏𝟏T​𝐱​(0)1𝑁superscript11𝑇𝐱0\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\mathbf{1}\mathbf{1}^{T}\mathbf{x}(0) (9)
=\displaystyle= 1N​J​𝐱​(0)1𝑁𝐽𝐱0\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{x}(0) (10)

and where 𝟏1\mathbf{1} is the vector of ones, see (6), and J=𝟏𝟏T𝐽superscript11𝑇J=\mathbf{1}\mathbf{1}^{T}. We next consider the iterative average consensus algorithm for both nonrandom and random topologies.

II-B1 Average consensus: Nonrandom topology

With the nonrandom topology defined by the supergraph G=(V,ℰ)𝐺𝑉ℰG=\left(V,\mathcal{E}\right), the state update by the average consensus proceeds according to the iterative algorithm

∀i≥0:xn​(i+1):for-all𝑖0subscript𝑥𝑛𝑖1\displaystyle\forall i\geq 0:\>\>\>x_{n}(i+1) =\displaystyle= 𝒲n​n​xn​(i)+∑l∈Ωn𝒲n​l​xl​(i)subscript𝒲𝑛𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛𝑖subscript𝑙subscriptΩ𝑛subscript𝒲𝑛𝑙subscript𝑥𝑙𝑖\displaystyle\mathcal{W}_{nn}x_{n}(i)+\sum_{l\in\Omega_{n}}\mathcal{W}_{nl}x_{l}(i) (11)
𝐱​(i+1)𝐱𝑖1\displaystyle\mathbf{x}(i+1) =\displaystyle= 𝒲​𝐱​(i)𝒲𝐱𝑖\displaystyle\mathcal{W}\mathbf{x}(i) (12)

where: ΩnsubscriptΩ𝑛\Omega_{n} is the neighborhood of sensor n𝑛n; 𝐱​(i)𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}(i) is the state vector collecting all states xn​(i)subscript𝑥𝑛𝑖x_{n}(i), 1≤n≤N1𝑛𝑁1\leq n\leq N; 𝒲n​lsubscript𝒲𝑛𝑙\mathcal{W}_{nl} is the weight of edge (n,l)𝑛𝑙(n,l); and the matrix of weights is 𝒲=[𝒲n​l]𝒲delimited-[]subscript𝒲𝑛𝑙\mathcal{W}=\left[\mathcal{W}_{nl}\right]. The sparsity of W𝑊W is determined by the underlying network connectivity, i.e., for n≠l𝑛𝑙n\neq l, the weight 𝒲n​l=0subscript𝒲𝑛𝑙0\mathcal{W}_{nl}=0 if (n,l)∉ℰ𝑛𝑙ℰ(n,l)\notin{\mathcal{E}}. Iterating (12),

𝐱​(i)𝐱𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{x}(i) =\displaystyle= (∏j=0i−1𝒲)​𝐱​(0)superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1𝒲𝐱0\displaystyle\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}\mathcal{W}\right)\mathbf{x}(0) (13)
=\displaystyle= 𝒲i​𝐱​(0)superscript𝒲𝑖𝐱0\displaystyle\mathcal{W}^{i}\mathbf{x}(0) (14)

A common choice for the weight matrix 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is the equal weights matrix, [22],

𝒲=I−α​ℒ𝒲𝐼𝛼ℒ\mathcal{W}=I-\alpha\mathcal{L} (15)

where ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is the Laplacian associated with ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, and α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0 is a constant independent of time i𝑖i. For the equal weights matrix and a connected network, given the ordering (5) of the eigenvalues of ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, and that α𝛼\alpha is nonnegative, the eigenvalues of 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} can be reordered as

1=λ1​(𝒲)≥λ2​(𝒲)≥⋯≥λN​(𝒲)1subscript𝜆1𝒲subscript𝜆2𝒲⋯subscript𝜆𝑁𝒲1=\lambda_{1}\left(\mathcal{W}\right)\geq\lambda_{2}\left(\mathcal{W}\right)\geq\cdots\geq\lambda_{N}\left(\mathcal{W}\right) (16)

The eigenvector corresponding to λ1​(𝒲)subscript𝜆1𝒲\lambda_{1}\left(\mathcal{W}\right) is still the vector 𝐮1​(𝒲)=1N​𝟏subscript𝐮1𝒲1𝑁1\mathbf{u}_{1}\left(\mathcal{W}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\mathbf{1}.

Reference [22] studies the problem of optimizing the nonzero weights 𝒲n​lsubscript𝒲𝑛𝑙\mathcal{W}_{nl} for maximizing convergence rate when the adjacency matrix 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is known. In particular, this reference shows that, for the equal weights case, fastest convergence is obtained with

α∗=2λ2​(ℒ)+λN​(ℒ)superscript𝛼2subscript𝜆2ℒsubscript𝜆𝑁ℒ\alpha^{*}=\frac{2}{\lambda_{2}\left(\mathcal{L}\right)+\lambda_{N}\left(\mathcal{L}\right)} (17)

In [9, 10, 11], we consider this equal weight 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} and show that the class of non-bipartite Ramanujan graphs provides the optimal (nonrandom) topology under a constraint on the number of network links M𝑀M, see also [12]. This optimality is in the asymptotic limit of large N𝑁N, see the references for details.

II-B2 Average consensus: Random topology

At each time i𝑖i, the graph G​(i)=(V,E​(i))𝐺𝑖𝑉𝐸𝑖G(i)=\left(V,E(i)\right) is random. The distributed average consensus algorithm still follows a vector iterative equation like (12), except now the weight matrices W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i) are time dependent and random. We focus on the equal weights problem,

W​(i)=I−α​L​(i)𝑊𝑖𝐼𝛼𝐿𝑖W(i)=I-\alpha L(i) (18)

where L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i) is the Laplacian of the random network at time i𝑖i. The L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i) are random iid matrices whose probability distribution is determined by the edge formation probability matrix P𝑃P. Likewise, the weight matrices W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i), i=0,1,…𝑖01…i=0,1,... are also iid random matrices. We often drop the time index i𝑖i in the random matrices L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i) and W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i) or their statistics. Iterating (12) with this time dependent weight matrix leads to

𝐱​(i)=(∏j=0i−1W​(j))​𝐱​(0)𝐱𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1𝑊𝑗𝐱0\mathbf{x}(i)=\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}W(j)\right)\mathbf{x}(0) (19)

Since the weights Wn​lsubscript𝑊𝑛𝑙W_{nl} are random, the state 𝐱​(i)𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}(i) is also a random vector. Section IV analyzes the influence of the topology on the convergence properties as we iterate (19).

III Preliminary Results

Subsection II-B2 describes the random topology model. The supergraph G=(V,ℰ)𝐺𝑉ℰG=\left(V,\mathcal{E}\right) is connected and P𝑃P is the matrix of edge formation probabilities. Since the A​(i)𝐴𝑖A(i), L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i), and W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i) are iid

A¯¯𝐴\displaystyle\overline{A} =\displaystyle= E​[A​(i)]𝐸delimited-[]𝐴𝑖\displaystyle E\left[A(i)\right] (20)
L¯¯𝐿\displaystyle\overline{L} =\displaystyle= E​[L​(i)]𝐸delimited-[]𝐿𝑖\displaystyle E\left[L(i)\right] (21)
W¯¯𝑊\displaystyle\overline{W} =\displaystyle= E​[W​(i)]𝐸delimited-[]𝑊𝑖\displaystyle E\left[W(i)\right] (22)
=\displaystyle= I−α​L¯𝐼𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle I-\alpha\overline{L} (23)

i.e., their means are time independent. We establish properties of the Laplacian, Subsection III-A, and weight matrices, Subsection III-B, needed when studying the random topology and random topology with communication cost constraint problems in sections IV through VI.

III-A Laplacian

We list some properties of the mean Laplacian and bound the expected value of the algebraic connectivity of the random Laplacians by the algebraic connectivity of the mean Laplacian.

Lemma 1

The mean adjacency matrix A¯¯𝐴\overline{A} and mean Laplacian are given by

A¯¯𝐴\displaystyle\overline{A} =\displaystyle= P𝑃\displaystyle P (24)
L¯n​lsubscript¯𝐿𝑛𝑙\displaystyle\overline{L}_{nl} =\displaystyle= {∑m=1NPn​mif n=l−Pn​lotherwisecasessuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑁subscript𝑃𝑛𝑚if n=lsubscript𝑃𝑛𝑙otherwise\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\sum_{m=1}^{N}P_{nm}&\mbox{if $n=l$}\\ -P_{nl}&\mbox{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (27)

This Lemma is straightforward to prove. From the Lemma, it follows that the mean adjacency matrix A¯¯𝐴\overline{A} is not a (0,1)01(0,1) matrix. Similarly. from the structure of the matrix L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}, see eqn. (27), it follows that L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} can be interpreted as the weighted Laplacian of a graph G¯¯𝐺\overline{G} with non-negative link weights. In particular, the weight of the link (n,l)𝑛𝑙(n,l) of G¯¯𝐺\overline{G} is Pn​lsubscript𝑃𝑛𝑙P_{nl}. The properties of the mean Laplacian are similar to the properties of the Laplacian. We state them in the following two Lemmas.

Lemma 2

The mean Laplacian matrix L¯=E​[L​(j)],j=0,1,…formulae-sequence¯𝐿Edelimited-[]𝐿𝑗𝑗01…\overline{L}=\mbox{E}\left[L(j)\right],~{}j=0,1,... is positive semidefinite. Its eigenvalues can be arranged as

0=λ1​(L¯)≤λ2​(L¯)≤⋯≤λN​(L¯)0subscript𝜆1¯𝐿subscript𝜆2¯𝐿⋯subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿0=\lambda_{1}\left(\overline{L}\right)\leq\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)\leq\cdots\leq\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right) (28)

where the normalized eigenvector associated with the zero eigenvalue λ1​(L¯)subscript𝜆1¯𝐿\lambda_{1}\left(\overline{L}\right) is

𝐮1​(L¯)=1N​𝟏subscript𝐮1¯𝐿1𝑁1\mathbf{u}_{1}\left(\overline{L}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\mathbf{1} (29)
Proof.

Let 𝐳∈ℝN×1𝐳superscriptℝ𝑁1\mathbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1} be a non-zero vector. Then, from eqn. (27), we have

𝐳T​L¯​𝐳=∑n,lL¯n​l​zn​zl=12​∑n≠lPn​l​(zn−zl)2superscript𝐳𝑇¯𝐿𝐳subscript𝑛𝑙subscript¯𝐿𝑛𝑙subscript𝑧𝑛subscript𝑧𝑙12subscript𝑛𝑙subscript𝑃𝑛𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑛subscript𝑧𝑙2\mathbf{z}^{T}\overline{L}\mathbf{z}=\sum_{n,l}\overline{L}_{nl}z_{n}z_{l}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{n\neq l}P_{nl}(z_{n}-z_{l})^{2} (30)

Since the Pn​lsubscript𝑃𝑛𝑙P_{nl}’s are non-negative, L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} is positive semidefinite. Eqn.(29) follows readily from eqn.(30). ∎

Interpreting L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} as the weighted Laplacian of the graph G¯¯𝐺\overline{G}, we note that λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0 implies that G¯¯𝐺\overline{G} is not connected (see [23, 19].) In other words, if λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0, then G¯¯𝐺\overline{G} has at least two disconnected components; hence, L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} takes the form of a block diagonal matrix (after permuting the rows and columns). Such matrices are called reducible matrices. Also, it immediately follows (see [23]) that, if L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} is irreducible, then λ2​(L¯)≠0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)\neq 0. Thus, we get the following Lemma.

Lemma 3

Let the mean Laplacian be the weighted Laplacian for a graph G¯¯𝐺\overline{G}.

λ2​(L¯)>0⟺L¯ is irreducible⟺G¯​is connected⟺subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0L¯ is irreducible⟺¯𝐺is connected\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0\Longleftrightarrow\mbox{$\overline{L}$ is irreducible}\Longleftrightarrow\overline{G}\>\mbox{is connected} (31)

The convergence results in Section IV-A on the average consensus involve the mean E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right], which is manifestly difficult to compute. A much easier quantity to compute is λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right). We relate here the two. First, we show that λ2​(L)subscript𝜆2𝐿\lambda_{2}(L) is a concave function of L𝐿L.

Lemma 4

λ2​(L)subscript𝜆2𝐿\lambda_{2}(L) is a concave function of L𝐿L.

Proof.

From the Courant-Fisher Theorem (see [19, 20])

λ2​(L)=min𝐳⊥𝟏⁡𝐳T​L​𝐳𝐳T​𝐳subscript𝜆2𝐿subscriptbottom𝐳1superscript𝐳𝑇𝐿𝐳superscript𝐳𝑇𝐳\lambda_{2}(L)=\min_{\mathbf{z}\bot\mathbf{1}}\frac{\mathbf{z}^{T}L\mathbf{z}}{\mathbf{z}^{T}\mathbf{z}} (32)

Then for any two Laplacians L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} and L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} and 0≤t≤10𝑡10\leq t\leq 1 we have

λ2​(t​L1+(1−t)​L2)subscript𝜆2𝑡subscript𝐿11𝑡subscript𝐿2\displaystyle\lambda_{2}(tL_{1}+(1-t)L_{2}) =\displaystyle= min𝐳⊥𝟏⁡𝐳T​(t​L1+(1−t)​L2)​𝐳𝐳T​𝐳subscriptbottom𝐳1superscript𝐳𝑇𝑡subscript𝐿11𝑡subscript𝐿2𝐳superscript𝐳𝑇𝐳\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{z}\bot\mathbf{1}}\frac{\mathbf{z}^{T}(tL_{1}+(1-t)L_{2})\mathbf{z}}{\mathbf{z}^{T}\mathbf{z}}
≥\displaystyle\geq t​min𝐳⊥𝟏⁡𝐳T​L1​𝐳𝐳T​𝐳+(1−t)​min𝐳⊥𝟏⁡𝐳T​L2​𝐳𝐳T​𝐳𝑡subscriptbottom𝐳1superscript𝐳𝑇subscript𝐿1𝐳superscript𝐳𝑇𝐳1𝑡subscriptbottom𝐳1superscript𝐳𝑇subscript𝐿2𝐳superscript𝐳𝑇𝐳\displaystyle t\min_{\mathbf{z}\bot\mathbf{1}}\frac{\mathbf{z}^{T}L_{1}\mathbf{z}}{\mathbf{z}^{T}\mathbf{z}}+(1-t)\min_{\mathbf{z}\bot\mathbf{1}}\frac{\mathbf{z}^{T}L_{2}\mathbf{z}}{\mathbf{z}^{T}\mathbf{z}}
=\displaystyle= t​λ2​(L1)+(1−t)​λ2​(L2)𝑡subscript𝜆2subscript𝐿11𝑡subscript𝜆2subscript𝐿2\displaystyle t\lambda_{2}(L_{1})+(1-t)\lambda_{2}(L_{2})

Thus λ2​(L)subscript𝜆2𝐿\lambda_{2}(L) is a concave function of L𝐿L. ∎

Lemma 5
E​[λ2​(L)]≤λ2​(L¯)Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]\leq\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) (34)
Proof.

Follows from Lemma 4 and Jensen’s inequality. ∎

III-B Weight matrices

We consider properties of the (random and mean) weight matrices.

Lemma 6

The eigenvalues of W¯¯𝑊\overline{W} are

1≤j≤N::1𝑗𝑁absent\displaystyle 1\leq j\leq N: λj​(W¯)=1−α​λj​(L¯)subscript𝜆𝑗¯𝑊1𝛼subscript𝜆𝑗¯𝐿\displaystyle\lambda_{j}\left(\overline{W}\right)=1-\alpha\lambda_{j}\left(\overline{L}\right) (35)
11\displaystyle 1 =\displaystyle= λ1​(W¯)≥λ2​(W¯)​⋯≥λN​(W¯)subscript𝜆1¯𝑊subscript𝜆2¯𝑊⋯subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊\displaystyle\lambda_{1}\left(\overline{W}\right)\geq\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right)\cdots\geq\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right) (36)

The eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue λ1​(W¯)subscript𝜆1¯𝑊\lambda_{1}\left(\overline{W}\right) is

𝐮1​(W¯)=1N​𝟏subscript𝐮1¯𝑊1𝑁1\mathbf{u}_{1}\left(\overline{W}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\mathbf{1} (37)

Similar results hold for W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i).

This Lemma follows immediately from the corresponding results on the mean Laplacian and the L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i).

We now consider results on the spectral norm and its expected value for the random matrices W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i) and their mean W¯¯𝑊\overline{W}. These results are used when studying convergence of the average consensus in Section IV.

Lemma 7

Let 𝐳∈ℝN×1𝐳superscriptℝ𝑁1\mathbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1} and ρ​(⋅)𝜌⋅\rho(\cdot) be the spectral radius. Then

∀W​(j):‖W​(j)​𝐳−1N​J​𝐳‖≤ρ​(W​(j)−1N​J)​‖𝐳−1N​J​𝐳‖:for-all𝑊𝑗norm𝑊𝑗𝐳1𝑁𝐽𝐳𝜌𝑊𝑗1𝑁𝐽norm𝐳1𝑁𝐽𝐳\forall\>W(j):\>\>\left\|W(j)\mathbf{z}-\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{z}\right\|\leq\rho\left(W(j)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\left\|\mathbf{z}-\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{z}\right\| (38)
Proof.

Decompose W​(j)𝑊𝑗W(j) through orthonormal eigenvectors as W​(j)=U​(j)​Λ​(j)​U​(j)T𝑊𝑗𝑈𝑗Λ𝑗𝑈superscript𝑗𝑇W(j)=U(j)\Lambda(j)U(j)^{T}. From eqn. (36), λ1​(W​(j))=1subscript𝜆1𝑊𝑗1\lambda_{1}(W(j))=1 with normalized eigenvector 𝐮1​(j)=1N​𝟏subscript𝐮1𝑗1𝑁1\mathbf{u}_{1}(j)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\mathbf{1}. Hence,

𝐳=1N​J​𝐳+∑k=2Nck​(j)​𝐮k​(j)𝐳1𝑁𝐽𝐳superscriptsubscript𝑘2𝑁subscript𝑐𝑘𝑗subscript𝐮𝑘𝑗\mathbf{z}=\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{z}+\sum_{k=2}^{N}c_{k}(j)\mathbf{u}_{k}(j) (39)

where ck​(j)=𝐮k​(j)T​𝐳,k=2,…,Nformulae-sequencesubscript𝑐𝑘𝑗subscript𝐮𝑘superscript𝑗𝑇𝐳𝑘2…𝑁c_{k}(j)=\mathbf{u}_{k}(j)^{T}\mathbf{z},~{}k=2,...,N. Then

W​(j)​𝐳=1N​J​𝐳+∑k=2Nck​(j)​λk​(W​(j))​𝐮k​(j)𝑊𝑗𝐳1𝑁𝐽𝐳superscriptsubscript𝑘2𝑁subscript𝑐𝑘𝑗subscript𝜆𝑘𝑊𝑗subscript𝐮𝑘𝑗W(j)\mathbf{z}=\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{z}+\sum_{k=2}^{N}c_{k}(j)\lambda_{k}(W(j))\mathbf{u}_{k}(j) (40)

It follows that

‖W​(j)​𝐳−1N​J​𝐳‖norm𝑊𝑗𝐳1𝑁𝐽𝐳\displaystyle\left\|W(j)\mathbf{z}-\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{z}\right\| =\displaystyle= ‖∑k=2Nck​(j)​λk​(W​(j))​𝐮k​(j)‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝑘2𝑁subscript𝑐𝑘𝑗subscript𝜆𝑘𝑊𝑗subscript𝐮𝑘𝑗\displaystyle\left\|\sum_{k=2}^{N}c_{k}(j)\lambda_{k}(W(j))\mathbf{u}_{k}(j)\right\|
≤\displaystyle\leq ρ​(W​(j)−1N​J)​‖∑k=2Nck​(j)​𝐮k​(j)‖𝜌𝑊𝑗1𝑁𝐽normsuperscriptsubscript𝑘2𝑁subscript𝑐𝑘𝑗subscript𝐮𝑘𝑗\displaystyle\rho\left(W(j)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\left\|\sum_{k=2}^{N}c_{k}(j)\mathbf{u}_{k}(j)\right\|
=\displaystyle= ρ​(W​(j)−1N​J)​‖𝐳−1N​J​𝐳‖𝜌𝑊𝑗1𝑁𝐽norm𝐳1𝑁𝐽𝐳\displaystyle\rho\left(W(j)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\left\|\mathbf{z}-\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{z}\right\|

This proves the Lemma. ∎

Lemma 8

We have

ρ​(W¯−1N​J)𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right) =\displaystyle= max⁡(|λ2​(W¯)|,|λN​(W¯)|)=max⁡(λ2​(W¯),−λN​(W¯))subscript𝜆2¯𝑊subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊subscript𝜆2¯𝑊subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊\displaystyle\max\left(|\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right)|,|\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right)|\right)=\max\left(\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right),-\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right)\right) (42)
ρ​(W​(i)−1N​J)𝜌𝑊𝑖1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\rho\left(W(i)-\frac{1}{N}J\right) =\displaystyle= max⁡(|λ2​(W​(i))|,|λN​(W​(i))|)=max⁡(λ2​(W​(i)),−λN​(W​(i)))subscript𝜆2𝑊𝑖subscript𝜆𝑁𝑊𝑖subscript𝜆2𝑊𝑖subscript𝜆𝑁𝑊𝑖\displaystyle\max\left(|\lambda_{2}\left(W(i)\right)|,|\lambda_{N}\left(W(i)\right)|\right)=\max\left(\lambda_{2}\left(W(i)\right),-\lambda_{N}\left(W(i)\right)\right) (43)
Proof.

We prove only the Lemma for W¯¯𝑊\overline{W}. Matrix 1N​J1𝑁𝐽\frac{1}{N}J is rank one, and the its non-zero eigenvalue is 111 with normalized eigenvector 1N​𝟏1𝑁1\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\mathbf{1}. Hence, from eqn. (36), the eigenvalues of (W¯−1N​J)¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right) are 00 and λ2​(W¯),…,λN​(W¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝑊…subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right),...,\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right). By the definition of spectral radius and eqn. (36),

ρ​(W¯−1N​J)=max⁡(0,|λ2​(W¯)|,…,|λN​(W¯)|)=max⁡(|λ2​(W¯)|,|λN​(W¯)|)𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽0subscript𝜆2¯𝑊…subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊subscript𝜆2¯𝑊subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)=\max\left(0,|\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right)|,...,|\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right)|\right)=\max\left(|\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right)|,|\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right)|\right) (44)

Also, noting that λ2​(W¯)≥λN​(W¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝑊subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right)\geq\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right), it follows from eqn. (44) that

ρ​(W¯−1N​J)=max⁡(λ2​(W¯),−λN​(W¯))𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽subscript𝜆2¯𝑊subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝑊\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)=\max\left(\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right),-\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{W}\right)\right) (45)

∎

We now consider the convexity of the spectral norm as a function of α𝛼\alpha and L𝐿L.

Lemma 9

For a given L𝐿L, ρ​(W−1N​J)𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right) is a convex function of α𝛼\alpha. For a given α𝛼\alpha, ρ​(W−1N​J)𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right) is a convex function of L𝐿L.

Proof.

We prove the convexity with respect to α𝛼\alpha only. Let α1,α2∈ℝsubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2ℝ\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2}\in\mathbb{R} and 0≤t≤10𝑡10\leq t\leq 1. For symmetric matrices the spectral radius is equal to the matrix 2-norm. We get

ρ​(I−(t​α1+(1−t)​α2)​L−1N​J)𝜌𝐼𝑡subscript𝛼11𝑡subscript𝛼2𝐿1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\rho\left(I-\left(t\alpha_{1}+(1-t)\alpha_{2}\right)L-\frac{1}{N}J\right) =\displaystyle= ‖I−t​α1​L−(1−t)​α2​L−1N​J‖2subscriptnorm𝐼𝑡subscript𝛼1𝐿1𝑡subscript𝛼2𝐿1𝑁𝐽2\displaystyle\left\|I-t\alpha_{1}L-(1-t)\alpha_{2}L-\frac{1}{N}J\right\|_{2} (46)
=\displaystyle= ‖t​(I−α1​L−1N​J)+(1−t)​(I−α2​L−1N​J)‖2subscriptnorm𝑡𝐼subscript𝛼1𝐿1𝑁𝐽1𝑡𝐼subscript𝛼2𝐿1𝑁𝐽2\displaystyle\left\|t\left(I-\alpha_{1}L-\frac{1}{N}J\right)+(1-t)\left(I-\alpha_{2}L-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right\|_{2}
≤\displaystyle\leq ‖t​(I−α1​L−1N​J)‖2+‖(1−t)​(I−α2​L−1N​J)‖2subscriptnorm𝑡𝐼subscript𝛼1𝐿1𝑁𝐽2subscriptnorm1𝑡𝐼subscript𝛼2𝐿1𝑁𝐽2\displaystyle\left\|t\left(I-\alpha_{1}L-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right\|_{2}+\left\|(1-t)\left(I-\alpha_{2}L-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right\|_{2}
=\displaystyle= t​ρ​(I−α1​L−1N​J)+(1−t)​ρ​(I−α2​L−1N​J)𝑡𝜌𝐼subscript𝛼1𝐿1𝑁𝐽1𝑡𝜌𝐼subscript𝛼2𝐿1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle t\rho\left(I-\alpha_{1}L-\frac{1}{N}J\right)+(1-t)\rho\left(I-\alpha_{2}L-\frac{1}{N}J\right)

that proves the Lemma. ∎

The next Lemma considers the convexity of the expected value of the spectral norm, taken over the probability distribution of the Laplacian. The following Lemma bounds E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right].

Lemma 10

For a given probability distribution (and hence P𝑃P) of L𝐿L, E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right] is convex on α𝛼\alpha.

Proof.

The convexity of E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right] follows from Lemma 9, eqn. (46), and the properties of Lebesgue integration. ∎

Lemma 11

For a given choice of α𝛼\alpha,

E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]≥ρ​(W¯−1N​J)Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]\geq\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right) (47)
Proof.

The Lemma follows from Lemma 9 and Jensen’s inequality. ∎

IV Convergence of Average Consensus: Random Topology

For average consensus in random topologies, we start by considering the convergence of the state

∀𝐱​(0)∈ℝN×1:limi→∞𝐱​(i)=𝐱avg:for-all𝐱0superscriptℝ𝑁1subscript→𝑖𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avg\forall\mathbf{x}(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1}:\>\>\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\mathbf{x}(i)=\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}} (48)

in some appropriate probabilistic sense. Subsection IV-A studies convergence of the mean vector, E​[𝐱​(i)]Edelimited-[]𝐱𝑖\mbox{E}\left[\mathbf{x}(i)\right], Subsection IV-B considers convergence in the mean-square-sense (mss), and almost sure convergence (convergence with probability 1) is treated in Subsection IV-C.

IV-A Mean state convergence

The sequence of expected state vectors converges if

limi→∞‖E​𝐱​(i)−𝐱avg‖=0subscript→𝑖normE𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avg0\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\left\|\mbox{E}\mathbf{x}(i)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|=0 (49)

For simplicity, we assume ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| to be the ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}-norm. We analyze the convergence of the mean state vector in  IV-A1 and then study the topology that optimizes its convergence rate in IV-A2.

IV-A1 Mean state convergence

The mean state evolution is given in the following Lemma.

Lemma 12

Recall 𝐱avgsubscript𝐱avg\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}} given in (8). Then

E​𝐱​(i)−𝐱avg=(W¯−1N​J)i​(𝐱​(0)−𝐱avg)E𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avgsuperscript¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽𝑖𝐱0subscript𝐱avg\mbox{E}\mathbf{x}(i)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}=\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)^{i}(\mathbf{x}(0)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}) (50)
Proof.

Using eqn. (19) and the fact that the matrices W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i) are iid

E​[𝐱​(i)]=W¯i​𝐱​(0)Edelimited-[]𝐱𝑖superscript¯𝑊𝑖𝐱0\mbox{E}\left[\mathbf{x}(i)\right]=\overline{W}^{i}\mathbf{x}(0) (51)

The Lemma follows by recalling that 𝟏1\mathbf{1} is an eigenvector of W¯¯𝑊\overline{W}.

∎

Convergence of the mean is now straightforward.

Theorem 13

A necessary and sufficient condition for the mean to converge is

ρ​(W¯−1N​J)<1𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽1\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)<1 (52)
Proof.

Lemma 12 shows that the convergence of the mean is equivalent to deterministic distributed average consensus. The necessary and sufficient condition for convergence then follows from references [11, 24]. ∎

IV-A2 Fastest mean convergence topology

We introduce the definition of convergence factor.

Definition 14 (Mean convergence factor)

If ρ​(W¯−1N​J)<1𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽1\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)<1, we call ρ​(W¯−1N​J)𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right) the mean convergence factor of the consensus algorithm.

For fastest mean convergence, ρ​(W¯−1N​J)𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right) should be as small as possible. Hence, the optimal topology with respect to convergence of the mean state vector is the topology that minimizes this convergence factor. We address this problem in the following two Theorems.

We note that ρ​(W¯−1J​N)𝜌¯𝑊1𝐽𝑁\rho(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{J}N) is a function of both α𝛼\alpha and L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}. In the following Theorem, we state conditions on L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} that guarantee that we can choose an α𝛼\alpha for which there is convergence of the mean.

Theorem 15

A necessary condition for the mean to converge is

λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0 (53)

A sufficient condition is (53) and

0<α<2/λN​(L¯)0𝛼2subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿0<\alpha<2/\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right) (54)
Proof.

We first prove the necessary condition by contradiction. Let λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0. From eqn. (35), it follows that λ2​(W¯)=1subscript𝜆2¯𝑊1\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{W}\right)=1. Then, from eqn. (42), we have ρ​(W¯−1N​J)≥1𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽1\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\geq 1, for every choice of α𝛼\alpha. Hence, from Lemma 13, it follows that, if λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0, the mean vector does not converge for any choice of α𝛼\alpha. This proves the necessary condition.

For sufficiency, we assume that λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. Then, generalizing the results in [24] to non-binary (0−1)01(0-1) matrices, it can be shown that

ρ​(W¯−1N​J)<1​iff​  0<α<2/λN​(L¯)𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽1iff  0𝛼2subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)<1\>\>\mbox{\emph{iff}}\>\>0<\alpha<2/\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right)

which then guarantees convergence of the mean state vector. ∎

If λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0, Theorem 15 and eqn. (54) give the values of α𝛼\alpha that lead to the convergence of the mean vector in terms of λN​(L¯)subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right), a quantity easily evaluated since L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} is given by eqn. (27).

The following Theorem gives the choice of α𝛼\alpha leading to the fastest convergence of the mean.

Theorem 16

Let λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. Then the choice of α𝛼\alpha that minimizes ρ​(W¯−1N​J)𝜌¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽\rho\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right) and hence maximizes the convergence rate of the mean state vector is

α⋆=2λ2​(L¯)+λN​(L¯)superscript𝛼⋆2subscript𝜆2¯𝐿subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿\alpha^{\star}=\frac{2}{\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)+\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right)} (55)

The corresponding minimum ρ​(⋅)𝜌⋅\rho(\cdot) is

ρmin​(W¯−1N​J)=1−λ2​(L¯)/λN​(L¯)1+λ2​(L¯)/λN​(L¯)subscript𝜌min¯𝑊1𝑁𝐽1subscript𝜆2¯𝐿subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿1subscript𝜆2¯𝐿subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿\rho_{\mbox{\scriptsize min}}\left(\overline{W}-\frac{1}{N}J\right)=\frac{1-\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)/\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right)}{1+\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)/\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right)} (56)
Proof.

It follows by generalizing the result in [24] to non-binary matrices. ∎

This section derived necessary and sufficient conditions for the convergence of the mean in terms of λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right). Also, it provided the values of α𝛼\alpha that guarantee convergence when λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. The next Subsection considers mss convergence of average consensus.

IV-B Mean Square Convergence

This Section studies mean-square convergence, which implies convergence of the mean, but not the reverse. We say that the algorithm converges in the mean-square sense (mss) iff

∀𝐱​(0)∈ℝN×1:limi→∞E​‖𝐱​(i)−𝐱avg‖=0:for-all𝐱0superscriptℝ𝑁1subscript→𝑖Enorm𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avg0\forall\mathbf{x}(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1}:\>\>\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\mbox{E}\left\|\mathbf{x}(i)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|=0 (57)

We need the following lemma first.

Lemma 17

For any 𝐱​(0)∈ℝN×1𝐱0superscriptℝ𝑁1\mathbf{x}(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1}

‖𝐱​(i+1)−𝐱avg‖≤(∏j=0iρ​(W​(j)−1N​J))​‖𝐱​(0)−𝐱avg‖norm𝐱𝑖1subscript𝐱avgsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖𝜌𝑊𝑗1𝑁𝐽norm𝐱0subscript𝐱avg\left\|\mathbf{x}(i+1)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|~{}\leq\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i}\rho\left(W(j)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right)\left\|\mathbf{x}(0)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\| (58)
Proof.

We have

‖𝐱​(i+1)−𝐱avg‖norm𝐱𝑖1subscript𝐱avg\displaystyle\left\|\mathbf{x}(i+1)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\| =\displaystyle= ‖(∏j=0iW​(j))​𝐱​(0)−1N​J​𝐱​(0)‖normsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖𝑊𝑗𝐱01𝑁𝐽𝐱0\displaystyle\left\|\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i}W(j)\right)\mathbf{x}(0)-\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{x}(0)\right\|
=\displaystyle= ‖W​(i)​(∏j=0i−1W​(j)​𝐱​(0))−1N​J​(∏j=0i−1W​(j)​𝐱​(0))‖norm𝑊𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1𝑊𝑗𝐱01𝑁𝐽superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1𝑊𝑗𝐱0\displaystyle\left\|W(i)\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}W(j)\mathbf{x}(0)\right)-\frac{1}{N}J\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}W(j)\mathbf{x}(0)\right)\right\|

where we have used the fact that

1N​J​(∏j=0i−1W​(j)​𝐱​(0))=1N​J​𝐱​(0)1𝑁𝐽superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1𝑊𝑗𝐱01𝑁𝐽𝐱0\frac{1}{N}J\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}W(j)\mathbf{x}(0)\right)=\frac{1}{N}J\mathbf{x}(0)

From Lemma 7, it then follows

‖𝐱​(i+1)−𝐱avg‖norm𝐱𝑖1subscript𝐱avg\displaystyle\left\|\mathbf{x}(i+1)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\| ≤\displaystyle\leq ρ​(W​(i)−1N​J)​‖(∏j=0i−1W​(j)​𝐱​(0))−1N​J​(∏j=0i−1W​(j)​𝐱​(0))‖𝜌𝑊𝑖1𝑁𝐽normsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1𝑊𝑗𝐱01𝑁𝐽superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1𝑊𝑗𝐱0\displaystyle\rho\left(W(i)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\left\|\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}W(j)\mathbf{x}(0)\right)-\frac{1}{N}J\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}W(j)\mathbf{x}(0)\right)\right\|
=\displaystyle= ρ​(W​(i)−1N​J)​‖𝐱​(i)−𝐱avg‖𝜌𝑊𝑖1𝑁𝐽norm𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avg\displaystyle\rho\left(W(i)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\left\|\mathbf{x}(i)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|

Repeating the same argument for j=0​to​i𝑗0to𝑖j=0\>\mbox{to}\>i we finally get

‖𝐱​(i+1)−𝐱avg‖≤(∏j=0iρ​(W​(j)−1N​J))​‖𝐱​(0)−𝐱avg‖norm𝐱𝑖1subscript𝐱avgsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖𝜌𝑊𝑗1𝑁𝐽norm𝐱0subscript𝐱avg\left\|\mathbf{x}(i+1)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|~{}\leq\left(\prod_{j=0}^{i}\rho\left(W(j)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right)\left\|\mathbf{x}(0)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\| (61)

This proves the Lemma. ∎

The following Theorem gives a sufficient condition for mss convergence.

Theorem 18

If E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]<1Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽1\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]<1, the state vector sequence {𝐱​(i)}i=0∞superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖0\{\mathbf{x}(i)\}_{i=0}^{\infty} converges in the mss

limi→∞E​‖𝐱​(i)−𝐱avg‖=0,∀𝐱​(0)∈ℝN×1formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑖Enorm𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avg0for-all𝐱0superscriptℝ𝑁1\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\mbox{E}\left\|\mathbf{x}(i)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|=0,~{}\forall\mathbf{x}(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1} (62)
Proof.

Taking expectation on both sides of eqn. (58) in Lemma 17 and using the iid of the W​(j)𝑊𝑗W(j)’s

E​‖𝐱i−𝐱avg‖≤(E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)])i−1​‖𝐱0−𝐱avg‖Enormsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avgsuperscriptEdelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽𝑖1normsubscript𝐱0subscript𝐱avg\mbox{E}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|~{}\leq\left(\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]\right)^{i-1}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{0}-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\| (63)

where we dropped the index i𝑖i in W​(i)𝑊𝑖W(i). The Theorem then follows. ∎

Like the Definition 14 for mean convergence factor, we introduce the mss convergence factor. First, note that E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right] is a function of the weight α𝛼\alpha and the probability of edge formation matrix P𝑃P (or L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} from (27).)

Definition 19 (mss convergence factor, mss convergence rate)

If E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]<1Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽1\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]<1, call C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) and Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L}) the mss convergence factor and the mss convergence gain per iteration (or the mss convergence rate), respectively, where

C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) =\displaystyle= E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right] (64)
Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L}) =\displaystyle= −ln​C​(α,L¯)ln𝐶𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle-{\rm ln}\,\,C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) (65)
=\displaystyle= ln​(1E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)])ln1Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle{\rm ln}\left(\frac{1}{\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]}\right) (66)
Corollary 20

mss convergence cannot be faster than convergence of the mean vector.

The Corollary follows from the Theorem and Lemma 11.

Theorem 18 shows that the smaller the mss convergence factor C​(α,L¯)=E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]𝐶𝛼¯𝐿Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right)=\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right] is, the faster the mss convergence. The actual value of C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) depends both on the probability distribution of the Laplacian L𝐿L and the constant weight α𝛼\alpha. However, the probability distribution of L𝐿L must satisfy certain conditions to guarantee that there are values of α𝛼\alpha that lead to mss convergence. Otherwise, no choice of α𝛼\alpha will result in mss convergence. The next Theorem considers this issue. Before stating the Theorem, let dmaxsubscript𝑑maxd_{\mbox{\scriptsize{max}}} be the maximum degree of the graph with edge set E=ℰ𝐸ℰE=\mathcal{E} and define

αmss=12​dmaxsubscript𝛼mss12subscript𝑑max\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize{mss}}}=\frac{1}{2d_{\mbox{\scriptsize{max}}}} (67)
Theorem 21

There is an α𝛼\alpha such that the consensus algorithm converges in mss iff λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. In other words, if λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0, we can find an α𝛼\alpha, in particular, α=αmss𝛼subscript𝛼mss\alpha=\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}} defined in (67), that leads to mss convergence. If λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0, no choice of α𝛼\alpha will result in mss convergence.

Proof.

We first prove the sufficiency part. The proof is constructive, and we show that, if λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0, we can find an α𝛼\alpha for which

C​(α,L¯)=E​[ρ​(W−JN)]<1𝐶𝛼¯𝐿Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊𝐽𝑁1C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right)=\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{J}{N}\right)\right]<1

Convergence then follows from Theorem 18.

Let λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. By Lemma 3, L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} is irreducible. From irreducibility of L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}, with non-zero probability, we have graph realizations for which L𝐿L is irreducible and so λ2​(L)>0subscript𝜆2𝐿0\lambda_{2}(L)>0. In particular, with non-zero probability, we can have a realization for which the edge set E=ℰ𝐸ℰE=\mathcal{E}; by assumption, this network is irreducible and hence connected (because the corresponding Laplacian matrix has the same sparsity pattern of L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} with non-zero entries of L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} replaced by ones.) Hence, with non-zero probability, λ2​(L)>0subscript𝜆2𝐿0\lambda_{2}(L)>0, which makes E​[λ2​(L)]>0Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿0\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]>0. Thus we have

λ2​(L¯)>0⟹E​[λ2​(L)]>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0⟹Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0\Longrightarrow\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]>0 (68)

Let dmax​(G)subscript𝑑max𝐺d_{\mbox{\scriptsize{max}}}(G) be the maximum vertex degree of graph G𝐺G. Then, from spectral graph theory, see [23],

λN​(L​(G))≤2​dmax​(G)subscript𝜆𝑁𝐿𝐺2subscript𝑑max𝐺\lambda_{N}(L(G))\leq 2d_{\mbox{\scriptsize{max}}}(G) (69)

We now claim mss convergence for α=αmss𝛼subscript𝛼mss\alpha=\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}. From Lemma 8 and (35),

ρ​(W−1N​J)𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right) =\displaystyle= max⁡(λ2​(W),−λN​(W))subscript𝜆2𝑊subscript𝜆𝑁𝑊\displaystyle\max\left(\lambda_{2}(W),-\lambda_{N}(W)\right)
=\displaystyle= max⁡(1−αmss​λ2​(L),αmss​λN​(L)−1)1subscript𝛼msssubscript𝜆2𝐿subscript𝛼msssubscript𝜆𝑁𝐿1\displaystyle\max\left(1-\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\lambda_{2}(L),\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\lambda_{N}(L)-1\right)
=\displaystyle= 1−αmss​λ2​(L)1subscript𝛼msssubscript𝜆2𝐿\displaystyle 1-\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\lambda_{2}(L)

where the last step follows from the fact that from eqn. (69) and (67)

1−αmss​λ2​(L)≥0≥αmss​λN​(L)−11subscript𝛼msssubscript𝜆2𝐿0subscript𝛼msssubscript𝜆𝑁𝐿11-\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\lambda_{2}(L)\geq 0\geq\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\lambda_{N}(L)-1 (71)

Taking expectation on both sides of eqn. (IV-B), and since 0<E​[λ2​(L)]≤2​dmax0Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿2subscript𝑑max0<\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]\leq 2d_{\mbox{\scriptsize{max}}}, we get

C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) =\displaystyle= E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]
=\displaystyle= 1−αmss​E​[λ2​(L)]1subscript𝛼mssEdelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\displaystyle 1-\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]
<\displaystyle< 11\displaystyle 1

mss convergence then follows from Theorem 15. This proves the sufficiency part.

The necessary condition follows from the fact that, if λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0, Theorem 15 precludes convergence of the mean vector. Since, by Corollary 20, convergence of the mean is necessary for mss convergence, we conclude that, if λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0, no choice of α𝛼\alpha will result in mss convergence. ∎

Theorem 21 gives necessary and sufficient conditions on the probability distribution of the Laplacian L𝐿L for mean square convergence. This is significant as it relates mss convergence to the network topology. Because this condition is in terms of the algebraic connectivity of the mean Laplacian associated with the probability distribution of edge formation P𝑃P, it is straightforward to check.

IV-C Almost Sure Convergence

We extend the results of the earlier sections and show that λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0 is also a necessary and sufficient condition for a.s. convergence of the sequence {𝐱​(i)}i=0∞superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖0\left\{\mathbf{x}(i)\right\}_{i=0}^{\infty}. Before proceeding to a formal statement and proof of this, we recall some basic facts about the convergence of (scalar) random variables.

Definition 22 (A.S. Convergence of random variables)

Let {ξi}i=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑖0\left\{\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\right\}_{i=0}^{\infty} be a sequence of random variables defined on some common probability space (Ω,ℱ,ℙ)Ωℱℙ(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathbb{P}). Then {ξi}i=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑖0\left\{\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\right\}_{i=0}^{\infty} converges a.s. to another random variable ξ𝜉\mathbf{\xi} defined on (Ω,ℱ,ℙ)Ωℱℙ(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathbb{P}) (ξi→ξ​a.s.)→subscript𝜉𝑖𝜉a.s.(\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\rightarrow\mathbf{\xi}\mbox{a.s.}) if

ℙ(ω∈Ω:ξi(ω)→i→∞ξ(ω))=1\mathbb{P}\left(\omega\in\Omega~{}:~{}\mathbf{\xi}_{i}(\omega)\xrightarrow[i\rightarrow\infty]{}\mathbf{\xi}(\omega)\right)=1 (73)

This definition readily extends to random vectors, where a.s. convergence means a.s.  convergence of each component (see [25, 26].)
We also recall that mss convergence of a sequence of random variables {𝐱​(i)}i=0∞superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖0\left\{\mathbf{x}(i)\right\}_{i=0}^{\infty} implies convergence in probability through Chebyshev’s inequality. Also, we note that convergence in probability implies a.s. convergence of a subsequence (see [27, 26].)
We now formalize the theorem for almost sure convergence of the state vector sequence {𝐱​(i)}i=0∞superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖0\left\{\mathbf{x}(i)\right\}_{i=0}^{\infty}.

Theorem 23

A necessary and sufficient condition for a.s. convergence of the sequence {𝐱​(i)}i=0∞superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖0\left\{\mathbf{x}(i)\right\}_{i=0}^{\infty} is λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. In other words, if λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0, then there exists an α𝛼\alpha such that 𝐱​(i)→𝐱avg​a.s.→𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avga.s.\mathbf{x}(i)\rightarrow\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\mbox{a.s.} On the contrary, if λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0 then no choice of α𝛼\alpha leads to a.s. convergence.

Proof.

We prove the sufficiency part first. Like Theorem 21 we give a constructive proof. We claim that the choice of α=αmss=1/2​dmax𝛼subscript𝛼mss12subscript𝑑max\alpha=\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize{mss}}}=1/2d_{\mbox{\scriptsize{max}}} (see eqn.(67)) leads to a.s. convergence. To this end, define the sequence of random variables,

ξi=‖𝐱​(i)−𝐱avg‖1/2subscript𝜉𝑖superscriptnorm𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avg12\mathbf{\xi}_{i}=\left\|\mathbf{x}(i)-\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}\right\|^{1/2} (74)

It follows from the properties of finite dimensional real number sequences (see [28]) that

𝐱​(i)→𝐱avg​a.s.⇔ξi→0​a.s.⇔→𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱avga.s.→subscript𝜉𝑖0a.s.\mathbf{x}(i)\rightarrow\mathbf{x}_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}~{}\mbox{a.s.}\Leftrightarrow\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\rightarrow 0~{}\mbox{a.s.} (75)

From Theorem 21 we note that

ξi→m​s​s0𝑚𝑠𝑠→subscript𝜉𝑖0\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\xrightarrow{mss}0 (76)

Thus ξi→0→subscript𝜉𝑖0\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\rightarrow 0 in probability and there exists a subsequence {ξik}k=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜉subscript𝑖𝑘𝑘0\left\{\mathbf{\xi}_{i_{k}}\right\}_{k=0}^{\infty} which converges to 0 a.s. Also we note from eqn.(69) that 0≤αmss≤10subscript𝛼mss10\leq\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize{mss}}}\leq 1. Then, from eqn.(IV-B), it follows that

ρ​(W−1N​J)≤1𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽1\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\leq 1 (77)

Hence from Lemma 7 we have

ξi2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖2\displaystyle\mathbf{\xi}_{i}^{2} ≤\displaystyle\leq ρ​(W​(i−1)−1N​J)​ξi−12𝜌𝑊𝑖11𝑁𝐽superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖12\displaystyle\rho\left(W(i-1)-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\mathbf{\xi}_{i-1}^{2}
≤\displaystyle\leq ξi−12superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖12\displaystyle\mathbf{\xi}_{i-1}^{2}

Thus {ξi}i=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑖0\left\{\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\right\}_{i=0}^{\infty} is a non-increasing sequence of random variables, a subsequence of which converges a.s. to 0. By the properties of real valued sequences ξi→0​a.s.→subscript𝜉𝑖0a.s.\mathbf{\xi}_{i}\rightarrow 0~{}\mbox{a.s.} The sufficiency part then follows from (74).

The necessary part is trivial, because λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}(\overline{L})=0 implies that the network always separates into at least two components with zero probability of communication between them. Hence no weight assignment scheme can lead to a.s. convergence. ∎

A note on Theorems 21 and 23: We consider only equal weights, i.e., all the link weights are assigned the same weight α𝛼\alpha. However, it is interesting that, whatever the weights in particular, different weights for different links, a necessary condition for mss convergence (and a.s. convergence) is λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. This is because (as argued in Theorem 23) if λ2​(L¯)=0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)=0, the network separates into two components with zero probability of communication between each other. Hence, no weight assignment can lead to mss convergence. Thus, the necessary condition established in Theorems 21 and 23 for mss convergence and a.s. convergence respectively in the constant link weight case holds for the more general weight assignments also. In other words, if we have a weight assignment (with possibly different weights for different links) for which the consensus algorithm converges in mss (and a.s.), then we can always find a constant weight α𝛼\alpha for which the consensus algorithm converges in mss (and a.s.)

V MSS Convergence Rate

We study now the mss convergence of the algorithm through the convergence metrics given in Definitions 19. In the sequel, whenever we refer to convergence rate of the algorithm, we mean the mss convergence gain per iteration, Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L}), unless otherwise stated. We derive bounds on the mss convergence rate of the algorithm. We assume that λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. Hence, by Theorem 21, there exists α𝛼\alpha, in particular, αmsssubscript𝛼mss\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}, leading to mss convergence. However, given a particular distribution of the Laplacian L𝐿L, the actual choice of α𝛼\alpha plays a significant role in determining the convergence rate. Thus, given a particular distribution of L𝐿L, we must choose that value of α𝛼\alpha that maximizes the convergence speed. From Theorem 18, we note that, the smaller the mss-convergence factor C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) given by (64) is, the faster the convergence is. For a given edge formation probability distribution P𝑃P (and hence L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}), the value of C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) depends on α𝛼\alpha. Thus, to maximize convergence speed for a given P𝑃P, we perform the minimization

C∗​(L¯)superscript𝐶∗¯𝐿\displaystyle C^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) =\displaystyle= minα⁡C​(α,L¯)subscript𝛼𝐶𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle\min_{\alpha}~{}C(\alpha,\overline{L})
=\displaystyle= minα⁡E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]subscript𝛼Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\min_{\alpha}~{}\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]

We present the results in terms of the best achievable mss convergence rate Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}(\overline{L})

Sg∗​(L¯)=−ln​C∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿lnsuperscript𝐶∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}(\overline{L})=-{\rm ln}C^{\ast}(\overline{L}) (80)

The minimization in eqn. (V) is difficult. It depends on the probability distribution of the Laplacian L𝐿L. But, by Lemma 10, C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) is convex on α𝛼\alpha for a given L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}; so, its minimum is attainable using numerical procedures. In performing this minimization, we do not need to consider the entire real line for finding the optimal α𝛼\alpha. The following Lemma provides a range where the optimal α𝛼\alpha lies.

Lemma 24

Let λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0. Then

0<α∗<2λN​(L¯)0superscript𝛼∗2subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿0<\alpha^{\ast}<\frac{2}{\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right)} (81)
Proof.

Since λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0, by Theorem 21, we can find α𝛼\alpha that leads to mss convergence. But, a necessary condition for mss convergence is convergence of the mean vector. From section IV-A, the mean converges only if

0<α<2λN​(L¯)0𝛼2subscript𝜆𝑁¯𝐿0<\alpha<\frac{2}{\lambda_{N}\left(\overline{L}\right)} (82)

Hence, the optimal α∗superscript𝛼∗\alpha^{\ast} leading to fastest mss convergence must also belong to this range. ∎

We can bound the optimal mss convergence rate Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}(\overline{L}).

Lemma 25

If λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0, then

Sg∗​(L¯)≥ln​(11−αmss​E​[λ2​(L)])superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿ln11subscript𝛼mssEdelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}(\overline{L})\geq{\rm ln}\left(\frac{1}{1-\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]}\right) (83)
Proof.

By Theorem 21, if λ2​(L¯)>0subscript𝜆2¯𝐿0\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)>0, then α=αmss𝛼subscript𝛼mss\alpha=\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize{mss}}} leads to mss convergence and

C​(αmss,L¯)𝐶subscript𝛼mss¯𝐿\displaystyle C\left(\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}},\overline{L}\right) =\displaystyle= E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽\displaystyle\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right]
=\displaystyle= 1−αmss​E​[λ2​(L)]1subscript𝛼mssEdelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\displaystyle 1-\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]
≥\displaystyle\geq C∗​(L¯)superscript𝐶∗¯𝐿\displaystyle C^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) (85)

The Lemma then follows because

Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿\displaystyle S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}(\overline{L}) =\displaystyle= ln​(1C∗​(L¯))ln1superscript𝐶∗¯𝐿\displaystyle{\rm ln}\left(\frac{1}{C^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right)}\right) (86)
≥\displaystyle\geq ln​(1C​(αmss,L¯))ln1𝐶subscript𝛼mss¯𝐿\displaystyle{\rm ln}\left(\frac{1}{C\left(\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize{mss}}},\overline{L}\right)}\right) (87)
=\displaystyle= ln​(11−αmss​E​[λ2​(L)])ln11subscript𝛼mssEdelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\displaystyle{\rm ln}\left(\frac{1}{1-\alpha_{\mbox{\scriptsize mss}}\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]}\right) (88)

∎

VI Consensus With Communication Constraints: Topology Optimization

In the previous sections, we analyzed the impact of the probability distribution D𝐷D of the network topology on the mss convergence rate of the distributed average consensus algorithm. This section studies the problem of sensor network topology optimization for fast consensus in the presence of inter-sensor communication (or infrastructure) cost constraints. We assume equal link weights throughout.

We consider N𝑁N sensors and a symmetric cost matrix C𝐶C, where the entry Cn​lsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑙C_{nl} is the cost (communication or infrastructure) incurred per iteration when sensors n𝑛n and l𝑙l communicate. The goal is to design the connectivity graph that leads to the fastest convergence rate under a constraint on the total communication cost per iteration. Depending on the structure of the cost matrix C𝐶C and the network topology (deterministic or randomized), this optimization problem may have the following variants:

  1. 1.

    Fixed topology with equal costs: Here the entries Cn​lsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑙C_{nl} of the cost matrix C𝐶C are all equal and we look for the optimal fixed or deterministic topology leading to fastest convergence of the consensus algorithm. It is easy to see that the equal cost assumption translates into a constraint on the number of network links and the optimal solution is essentially the class of non-bipartite Ramanujan graphs (see [9, 10, 11].)

  2. 2.

    Fixed topology with different costs (FCCC): In this case the inter-sensor costs Cn​lsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑙C_{nl} may be different, and we seek the optimal fixed or deterministic topology leading to fastest convergence. This is a difficult combinatorial optimization problem and there is no closed form solution in general.

  3. 3.

    Random topology with different costs (RCCC): This is the most general problem, where the costs Cn​lsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑙C_{nl} may be different and we look for the optimal (random or deterministic) topology leading to the fastest convergence rate under a communication cost constraint. Because the network is random, it makes sense to constrain the (network) average (expected) communication cost per iteration. Likewise, convergence should also be interpreted in a probabilistic sense, for example, the mean square convergence. To summarize, in the RCCC problem, we are concerned with: (i) designing the optimal probability of edge formation matrix P𝑃P, (ii) under an average communication cost constraint, (iii) leading to the fastest mss convergence rate. RCCC reduces to FCCC, if the entries of the optimal P𝑃P are 0 or 1. In this sense, the RCCC problem relaxes the difficult combinatorial FCCC problem and, as we will see later, will usually lead to better overall solutions, especially under medium to low communication cost constraints. This is because with a fixed topology, we are forced to use the same network always, while in the random topology case we can occasionally make use of very good networks, still satisfying the cost constraint. We can draw an analogy between RCCC and gossip algorithms (see [15].) However the context and assumptions of the two problems are different. Reference [15] optimizes the gossip probabilities for a given network topology under the gossip protocol—only two nodes, randomly selected with gossip probability, can communicate at each iteration— and [15] does not impose a communication cost constraint. In contrast, we design the optimal (equal) weight α𝛼\alpha and the optimal P𝑃P matrix leading to the fastest mss convergence rate, under an average cost constraint. The topology solution that we determine gives the percentage of time a link is to be used, or, as another interpretation, the probability of error asssociated with reliable communication in a given link. Because signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) determines often the probability of error, enforcing the topology, i.e., P𝑃P, is like selecting the SNR for each link.

VI-A Random Topology with Communication Cost Constraints (RCCC)

We are given N𝑁N sensors. We model the cost of communication by an N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N matrix C=CT𝐶superscript𝐶𝑇C=C^{T}. The entry Cn​l≥0subscript𝐶𝑛𝑙0C_{nl}\geq 0, n≠l𝑛𝑙n\neq l, is the cost incurred by a single communication between nodes n𝑛n and l𝑙l. Entry Cn​l=+∞subscript𝐶𝑛𝑙C_{nl}=+\infty precludes sensors n𝑛n and l𝑙l from communicating. Let P𝑃P be the probability of edge formation matrix. The diagonal entries of P𝑃P are zero, although each node can access its data with zero cost. The P𝑃P matrix induces a probability distribution on the Laplacian L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i), which at time i𝑖i is a random instantiation based on the P𝑃P matrix. The total cost incurred at stage i𝑖i is

u​(i)𝑢𝑖\displaystyle u(i) =\displaystyle= −12​∑n≠lLn​l​(i)​Cn​l12subscript𝑛𝑙subscript𝐿𝑛𝑙𝑖subscript𝐶𝑛𝑙\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{n\neq l}L_{nl}(i)C_{nl}
=\displaystyle= −12​Tr​(C​L​(i))12Tr𝐶𝐿𝑖\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}(CL(i))

This follows from C𝐶C being symmetric with zero diagonal entries. Since L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i) is a random matrix, the cost uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} incurred at step i𝑖i is random. From (VI-A), the expected cost incurred at step i𝑖i is

∀i:E​[ui]−12​Tr​(C​L¯):for-all𝑖Edelimited-[]subscript𝑢𝑖12Tr𝐶¯𝐿\forall i:\>\>\mbox{E}\left[u_{i}\right]-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}\left(C\overline{L}\right) (90)

We consider the distributed averaging consensus model with equal link weights given in eqns. (12) and (18). From Section IV-B, mss convergence is determined by the convergence factor C​(α,L¯)=E​[ρ​(W−1N​J)]𝐶𝛼¯𝐿Edelimited-[]𝜌𝑊1𝑁𝐽C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right)=\mbox{E}\left[\rho\left(W-\frac{1}{N}J\right)\right] or the convergence rate Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L}) defined in (65). In particular, the smaller C​(α,L¯)𝐶𝛼¯𝐿C\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) (or larger Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L})) is, the faster the convergence rate. The expected cost per iteration step in eqn. (90) depends on L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} and hence P𝑃P, which are in 1↔1↔111\leftrightarrow 1 correspondence.

Let 𝒟​(U)𝒟𝑈\mathcal{D}(U) be the set of feasible L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} (and hence P𝑃P) given a constraint U𝑈U on the expected cost per step

𝒟​(U)={L¯:−12​Tr​(C​L¯)≤U}𝒟𝑈conditional-set¯𝐿12Tr𝐶¯𝐿𝑈\mathcal{D}(U)=\left\{\overline{L}:-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}\left(C\overline{L}\right)\leq U\right\} (91)

The RCCC problem can then be stated formally as:

RCCC: Problem formulation.

maxα,L¯⁡Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝛼¯𝐿subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle\max_{\alpha,\overline{L}}~{}S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right)\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\> (92)
subject toL¯subject to¯𝐿\displaystyle\mbox{subject to}\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\overline{L} =\displaystyle= L¯T∈ℝN×Nsuperscript¯𝐿𝑇superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁\displaystyle\overline{L}^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N}
−1≤1absent\displaystyle-1\leq L¯n​lsubscript¯𝐿𝑛𝑙\displaystyle\overline{L}_{nl} ≤0,n,l∈{1,..,N},n≠l\displaystyle\leq 0,~{}n,l\in\{1,..,N\},n\neq l
L¯​𝟏¯𝐿1\displaystyle\overline{L}\mathbf{1} =\displaystyle= 𝟎0\displaystyle\mathbf{0}
−12​Tr​(C​L¯)12Tr𝐶¯𝐿\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}\left(C\overline{L}\right) ≤\displaystyle\leq U𝑈\displaystyle U

The second inequality constraint comes from the fact that L¯n​l=−Pn​l,n≠lformulae-sequencesubscript¯𝐿𝑛𝑙subscript𝑃𝑛𝑙𝑛𝑙\overline{L}_{nl}=-P_{nl},~{}n\neq l. The other inequalities follow from the properties of the Laplacian and the cost constraint.

VI-B Alternate Randomized Consensus under Communication Cost Constraints (ARCCC)

The RCCC problem in (92) is very difficult to solve. We formulate an alternate randomized consensus under communication cost constraints (ARCCC) problem. We show successively: (i) ARCCC is convex and can be solved by fast numerical optimization procedures; (ii) ARCCC is a good approximation to (92); and (iii) ARCCC leads to topologies with good convergence rates. Point (i) is in this section, while points (ii) and (iii) are studied in Section VII-C where we analyze the performance of ARCCC.

ARCCC: Problem Formulation.

maxL¯⁡λ2​(L¯)subscript¯𝐿subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\displaystyle\max_{\overline{L}}~{}\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\> (93)
subject toL¯subject to¯𝐿\displaystyle\mbox{subject to}\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\>\overline{L} =\displaystyle= L¯T∈ℝN×Nsuperscript¯𝐿𝑇superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁\displaystyle\overline{L}^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N}
−1≤1absent\displaystyle-1\leq L¯n​lsubscript¯𝐿𝑛𝑙\displaystyle\overline{L}_{nl} ≤0,n,l∈{1,..,N},n≠l\displaystyle\leq 0,~{}n,l\in\{1,..,N\},n\neq l
L¯​𝟏¯𝐿1\displaystyle\overline{L}\mathbf{1} =\displaystyle= 𝟎0\displaystyle\mathbf{0}
−12​Tr​(C​L¯)12Tr𝐶¯𝐿\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}\left(C\overline{L}\right) ≤\displaystyle\leq U𝑈\displaystyle U
Lemma 26

The optimization problem ARCCC in (93) is convex.

Proof.

From Lemma 4, it follows that the objective λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) is a concave function of L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}. Also, the set of L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} satisfying the constraints forms a convex set. Hence, ARCCC maximizes a concave function over a convex set; so, it is convex. ∎

The optimization problem in Lemma 26 is a semidefinite programming (SDP) problem that can be solved numerically in efficient ways, see references [29, 30] for SDP solving methods (see also [31, 32] for constrained optimization of graph Laplacian eigenvalues.)

VII Topology Optimization: Performance Results

In this section, Subsection VII-A discusses in what sense the ARCCC topology optimization problem introduced in Section VI-B and eqn. (93) is a good approximation to the original RCCC topology optimization formulation of Section VI-A and eqn. (92). Subsection VII-B establishes bounds on the optimal value as a function of the communication constraint. Finally, Subsection VII-C illustrates by a numerical study that the ARCCC optimization obtains topologies for which the distributed consensus exhibits fast convergence.

VII-A ARCCC as a Good Approximation to RCCC

The difficulty with RCCC stems from the fact that it involves joint optimization over both α𝛼\alpha and L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}. For a given L¯¯𝐿\overline{L}, there is, in general, no closed form solution of

Sg∗​(L¯)=maxα∈ℝ⁡Sg​(α,L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿subscript𝛼ℝsubscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right)=\max_{\alpha\in\mathbb{R}}S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}\left(\alpha,\overline{L}\right) (94)

We first present a plausible argument of why ARCCC is a good surrogate for RCCC, and then present numerical results that justify this argument.

We present a plausible argument in two steps. First, we replace in RCCC the maximization of Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) by the maximization of E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]. We justify this step by noting that eqn. (88) bounds Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}(\overline{L}) from below and this lower bound shows that larger values of E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] lead to higher Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right). This suggests that, for a given set of distributions L¯∈𝒟​(U)¯𝐿𝒟𝑈\overline{L}\in\mathcal{D}(U), the quantity E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] may provide an ordering on the elements of 𝒟​(U)𝒟𝑈\mathcal{D}(U) with respect to the mss convergence rate Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right). Hence, a topology with fast convergence rate satisfying the communication constraint U𝑈U is provided by the distribution L¯∗∈𝒟​(U)superscript¯𝐿∗𝒟𝑈\overline{L}^{\ast}\in\mathcal{D}(U) that maximizes the quantity E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] over the set 𝒟​(U)𝒟𝑈\mathcal{D}(U).

This is not enough to get a reasonable topology optimization problem, since computing E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] is costly, because its evaluation requires costly Monte-Carlo simulations (see [13].) The second step replaces the optimization of E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] by the maximization of λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}), which simply involves computing the second eigenvalue of P=L¯𝑃¯𝐿P=\overline{L}, no Monte Carlo simulations being involved. This step is justified on the basis of Lemma 5, which upper-bounds E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] by λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}). This suggests that for E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] to be large, λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}) should be large.

Putting together the two steps, the RCCC problem in eqn. (92) is successively approximated by

Sg∗superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗\displaystyle S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast} =\displaystyle= maxα,L¯∈𝒟​(U)⁡Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝛼¯𝐿𝒟𝑈subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿\displaystyle\max_{\alpha,\overline{L}\in\mathcal{D}(U)}S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L})
≈\displaystyle\approx maxα⁡Sg​(α,L¯∗)subscript𝛼subscript𝑆g𝛼superscript¯𝐿∗\displaystyle\max_{\alpha}S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L}^{\ast})
=\displaystyle= Sg∗^^superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗\displaystyle\widehat{S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}}

where L¯∗superscript¯𝐿∗\overline{L}^{\ast} is given by

L¯∗=arg​maxL¯∈𝒟​(U)⁡λ2​(L¯)superscript¯𝐿∗argsubscript¯𝐿𝒟𝑈subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\overline{L}^{\ast}=\mbox{arg}~{}\max_{\overline{L}\in\mathcal{D}(U)}\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) (96)

In general, Sg∗^≤Sg∗^superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗\widehat{S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}}\leq S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}. If Sg​(α,L¯)subscript𝑆g𝛼¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}(\alpha,\overline{L}) was a non-decreasing function of λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}), we would have Sg∗^=Sg∗^superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗\widehat{S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}}=S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}.

We verify by a numerical study how and in what sense Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) in (94) increases with E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] and λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right). In our simulation, we choose a network with N=500𝑁500N=500 sensors and let the average degree davgsubscript𝑑avgd_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}} of the network vary in steps of 555 from 101010 to 404040. For each of these 777 values of davgsubscript𝑑avgd_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}, we construct 200 Erdös-Rényi random graphs by choosing at random M=davg​N/2𝑀subscript𝑑avg𝑁2M=d_{\mbox{\scriptsize{avg}}}N/2 edges of the N​(N−1)/2𝑁𝑁12N(N-1)/2 possible pairings of vertices in the network. For each of these 200 random graphs, we generate randomly a probability of formation matrix P𝑃P (hence a probability distribution of L𝐿L) by choosing for each edge a weight between 00 and 111 from a uniform random distribution. For each such P𝑃P matrix, we collect statistics on the convergence rate Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) and E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] by generating 400400400 possible L​(i)𝐿𝑖L(i). For each P𝑃P, we also obtain the corresponding λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}(\overline{L}) by eqn. (27). This is an extensive and computationally expensive simulation. Fig. 1 displays the results by plotting the convergence rate Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) with respect to E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right], left plot, and with respect to λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right), right plot. These two plots are remarkably similar and both show that, except for local oscillations, the trend of the convergence rate Sg∗​(L¯)superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗¯𝐿S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}\left(\overline{L}\right) is to increase with increasing E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right] and λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right). Of course, λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) is much easier to evaluate than E​[λ2​(L)]Edelimited-[]subscript𝜆2𝐿\mbox{E}\left[\lambda_{2}(L)\right]. The plots in Fig. 1 confirm that, given a class 𝒟​(U)𝒟𝑈\mathcal{D}(U) of probability distributions of L𝐿L, we can set an ordering in 𝒟​(U)𝒟𝑈\mathcal{D}(U) by evaluating the corresponding λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right)’s, in the sense that a larger value of λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) leads to a better convergence rate in general (see also [13], where part of these results were presented.) This study shows that optimal topologies with respect to ARCCC should be good topologies with respect to RCCC.

VII-B ARCCC: Performance Analysis

To gain insight into ARCCC, we study the dependence of the maximum value of its functional

ϕ​(U)=maxL¯∈𝒟​(U)⁡λ2​(L¯)italic-ϕ𝑈subscript¯𝐿𝒟𝑈subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\phi(U)=\max_{\overline{L}\in\mathcal{D}(U)}\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) (97)

on the value of the communication cost constraint U𝑈U. We first establish the concavity of ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\phi(U).

Lemma 27

Given a cost matrix C𝐶C, ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\phi(U) is a concave function of U𝑈U.

Proof.

Let 0≤U1≤U20subscript𝑈1subscript𝑈20\leq U_{1}\leq U_{2} and 0≤t≤10𝑡10\leq t\leq 1. Consider the matrices L¯1∗subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗1\overline{L}^{\ast}_{1} and L¯2∗subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗2\overline{L}^{\ast}_{2}, such that

λ2​(L¯1∗)=ϕ​(U1)​and​λ2​(L¯2∗)=ϕ​(U2)subscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗1italic-ϕsubscript𝑈1andsubscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗2italic-ϕsubscript𝑈2\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}^{\ast}_{1}\right)=\phi\left(U_{1}\right)\>\>\mbox{and}\>\>\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}^{\ast}_{2}\right)=\phi\left(U_{2}\right)

It follows that
