L¯1∗∈𝒟​(U1)​and​L¯2∗∈𝒟​(U2)subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗1𝒟subscript𝑈1andsubscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗2𝒟subscript𝑈2\overline{L}^{\ast}_{1}\in\mathcal{D}(U_{1})\>\>\mbox{and}\>\>\overline{L}^{\ast}_{2}\in\mathcal{D}(U_{2})

Let L¯=t​L¯1∗+(1−t)​L¯2∗¯𝐿𝑡subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗11𝑡subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗2\overline{L}=t\overline{L}^{\ast}_{1}+(1-t)\overline{L}^{\ast}_{2}. Then,

−12​Tr​{C​L¯}12Tr𝐶¯𝐿\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}\left\{C\overline{L}\right\} =\displaystyle= t​(−12​Tr​{C​L¯1∗})+(1−t)​(−12​Tr​{C​L¯2∗})𝑡12Tr𝐶subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗11𝑡12Tr𝐶subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗2\displaystyle t\left(-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}\left\{C\overline{L}^{\ast}_{1}\right\}\right)+(1-t)\left(-\frac{1}{2}\mbox{Tr}\left\{C\overline{L}^{\ast}_{2}\right\}\right)
≤\displaystyle\leq t​U1+(1−t)​U2𝑡subscript𝑈11𝑡subscript𝑈2\displaystyle tU_{1}+(1-t)U_{2}

Hence L¯∈𝒟​(t​U1+(1−t)​U2)¯𝐿𝒟𝑡subscript𝑈11𝑡subscript𝑈2\overline{L}\in\mathcal{D}\left(tU_{1}+(1-t)U_{2}\right). From this we conclude that

ϕ​(t​U1+(1−t)​U2)≥λ2​(L¯)italic-ϕ𝑡subscript𝑈11𝑡subscript𝑈2subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\phi\left(tU_{1}+(1-t)U_{2}\right)\geq\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) (99)

Now, since λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) is a concave function of L¯¯𝐿\overline{L} (see Lemma 4), we get

λ2​(L¯)subscript𝜆2¯𝐿\displaystyle\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}\right) =\displaystyle= λ2​(t​L¯1∗+(1−t)​L¯2∗)subscript𝜆2𝑡subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗11𝑡subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗2\displaystyle\lambda_{2}\left(t\overline{L}^{\ast}_{1}+(1-t)\overline{L}^{\ast}_{2}\right)
≥\displaystyle\geq t​λ2​(L¯1∗)+(1−t)​λ2​(L¯2∗)𝑡subscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗11𝑡subscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscript¯𝐿∗2\displaystyle t\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}^{\ast}_{1}\right)+(1-t)\lambda_{2}\left(\overline{L}^{\ast}_{2}\right)
=\displaystyle= t​ϕ​(U1)+(1−t)​ϕ​(U2)𝑡italic-ϕsubscript𝑈11𝑡italic-ϕsubscript𝑈2\displaystyle t\phi\left(U_{1})+(1-t)\phi(U_{2}\right)

Finally, using eqns.(99 and VII-B), we get

ϕ​(t​U1+(1−t)​U2)≥t​ϕ​(U1)+(1−t)​ϕ​(U2)italic-ϕ𝑡subscript𝑈11𝑡subscript𝑈2𝑡italic-ϕsubscript𝑈11𝑡italic-ϕsubscript𝑈2\phi\left(tU_{1}+(1-t)U_{2}\right)\geq t\phi\left(U_{1}\right)+(1-t)\phi\left(U_{2}\right) (101)

that establishes the concavity of ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\phi(U). ∎

We use the concavity of ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\phi(U) to derive an upperbound on ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\phi(U). Recall that ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is the edge set of the complete graph–the set of all possible N​(N−1)/2𝑁𝑁12N(N-1)/2 edges. Define the set of realizable edges ℰ⊆ℳℰℳ\mathcal{E}\subseteq\mathcal{M} by

ℰ​{(n,l)∈ℳ:Cn​l<∞}ℰconditional-set𝑛𝑙ℳsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑙\mathcal{E}\left\{(n,l)\in\mathcal{M}~{}:~{}C_{nl}<\infty\right\} (102)

and by Lℰsubscript𝐿ℰL_{\mathcal{E}} the associated Laplacian. Also, let the total cost Ctotsubscript𝐶totC_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}

Ctot=∑(n,l)∈ℰCn​lsubscript𝐶totsubscript𝑛𝑙ℰsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑙C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}=\sum_{(n,l)~{}\in~{}\mathcal{E}}C_{nl} (103)

The quantity Ctotsubscript𝐶totC_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}} is the communication cost per iteration when all the realizable links are used.

Lemma 28

Let C𝐶C be a cost matrix and U≥Ctot𝑈subscript𝐶totU\geq C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}. Then ϕ​(U)=λ2​(Lℰ)italic-ϕ𝑈subscript𝜆2subscript𝐿ℰ\phi(U)=\lambda_{2}\left(L_{\mathcal{E}}\right). If ℰ=ℳℰℳ\mathcal{E}=\mathcal{M}, then ϕ​(U)=Nitalic-ϕ𝑈𝑁\phi(U)=N.

Proof.

The best possible case is when all the network links (n,l)∈ℰ𝑛𝑙ℰ(n,l)\in\mathcal{E} have probability of formation Pn​l=1subscript𝑃𝑛𝑙1P_{nl}=1 (the links in ℰCsuperscriptℰ𝐶\mathcal{E}^{C} must have zero probability of formation to satisfy the cost constraint.) In this case, L¯=Lℰ¯𝐿subscript𝐿ℰ\overline{L}=L_{\mathcal{E}}. Now, if U≥Ctot𝑈subscript𝐶totU\geq C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}, then Lℰ∈𝒟​(U)subscript𝐿ℰ𝒟𝑈L_{\mathcal{E}}\in\mathcal{D}(U) and hence the proof follows. The case ℰ=ℳℰℳ\mathcal{E}=\mathcal{M} follows from the fact that, for a complete graph, λ2​(Lℳ)=Nsubscript𝜆2subscript𝐿ℳ𝑁\lambda_{2}\left(L_{\mathcal{M}}\right)=N (see [19, 20].) ∎

Using the concavity of ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\phi(U) (Lemma 27), we now derive a performance bound when U≤Ctot𝑈subscript𝐶totU\leq C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}.

Lemma 29

Let C𝐶C be a cost matrix. Then

ϕ​(U)≥(UCtot)​λ2​(Lℰ),0≤U≤Ctotformulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ𝑈𝑈subscript𝐶totsubscript𝜆2subscript𝐿ℰ0𝑈subscript𝐶tot\phi(U)\geq\left(\frac{U}{C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}}\right)\lambda_{2}\left(L_{\mathcal{E}}\right),~{}~{}0\leq U\leq C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}} (104)

If ℰ=ℳℰℳ\mathcal{E}=\mathcal{M}, then

ϕ​(U)≥(UCtot)​N,0≤U≤Ctotformulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ𝑈𝑈subscript𝐶tot𝑁0𝑈subscript𝐶tot\phi(U)\geq\left(\frac{U}{C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}}\right)N,~{}~{}0\leq U\leq C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}} (105)
Proof.

From Lemma 28, ϕ​(Ctot)​λ2​(Lℰ)italic-ϕsubscript𝐶totsubscript𝜆2subscript𝐿ℰ\phi\left(C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}\right)\lambda_{2}\left(L_{\mathcal{E}}\right). Then, using the concavity of ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\phi(U) (see Lemma 27) and the fact that ϕ​(0)=0italic-ϕ00\phi(0)=0, we have, for 0≤U≤Ctot0𝑈subscript𝐶tot0\leq U\leq C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}},

ϕ​(U)italic-ϕ𝑈\displaystyle\phi(U) =\displaystyle= ϕ​((UCtot)​Ctot)italic-ϕ𝑈subscript𝐶totsubscript𝐶tot\displaystyle\phi\left(\left(\frac{U}{C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}}\right)C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}\right)
≥\displaystyle\geq (UCtot)​ϕ​(Ctot)𝑈subscript𝐶totitalic-ϕsubscript𝐶tot\displaystyle\left(\frac{U}{C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}}\right)\phi(C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}})
=\displaystyle= (UCtot)​λ2​(Lℰ)𝑈subscript𝐶totsubscript𝜆2subscript𝐿ℰ\displaystyle\left(\frac{U}{C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}}\right)\lambda_{2}\left(L_{\mathcal{E}}\right)

This proves the Lemma. The case ℰ=ℳℰℳ\mathcal{E}=\mathcal{M} follows easily. ∎

Lemma 28 states what should be expected, namely: to achieve the optimal performance λ2​(Lℰ)subscript𝜆2subscript𝐿ℰ\lambda_{2}\left(L_{\mathcal{E}}\right) one needs no more than Ctotsubscript𝐶totC_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}. Lemma 29 is interesting since it states that the ARCCC optimal topology may achieve better performance than the fraction of communication cost it uses would lead us to expect. The numerical study in the next Section helps to quantify these qualitative assessments.

VII-C Numerical Studies: ARCCC

This Section solves the ARCCC semidefinite programming optimization given by (93). It solves for P𝑃P, which assigns to each realizable link its probability of error (aka, SNR), or the fraction of time it is expected to be active. We compare the ARCCC optimal topology to a fixed radius connectivity (FRC) topology detailed below. The sensor network is displayed on the left of Fig. 2. We deploy N=80𝑁80N=80 sensors uniformly on a 25×25252525\times 25 square grid on the plane. The set ℰℰ\mathcal{E} of realizable links is constructed by choosing |ℰ|=9​Nℰ9𝑁|\mathcal{E}|=9N edges randomly from the set ℳℳ\mathcal{M} of all possible edges. We assume a geometric propagation model: the communication cost is proportional to the square of the Euclidean distance dn​lsubscript𝑑𝑛𝑙d_{nl} between sensors n𝑛n and l𝑙l

Cn​l={η​dn​l2if (n,l)∈ℰ∞otherwisesubscript𝐶𝑛𝑙cases𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑛𝑙2if (n,l)∈ℰotherwiseC_{nl}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\eta d_{nl}^{2}&\mbox{if $(n,l)\in\mathcal{E}$}\\ \infty&\mbox{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (107)

where η𝜂\eta is an appropriately chosen constant. With the FRC network, a sensor n𝑛n communicates with all other sensors l𝑙l (Cn​l<∞subscript𝐶𝑛𝑙C_{nl}<\infty) that lie within a radius R𝑅R. The FRC topology is an instantiation of a fixed, i.e., not random, topology with a fixed cost incurred per iteration.

Fig. 2 on the right plots, as a function of the cost constraint U𝑈U, the per step convergence gain Sg=Sg∗^subscript𝑆g^superscriptsubscript𝑆g∗S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}=\widehat{S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}^{\ast}} for the ARCCC optimal topology (top blue line) and the per step convergence gain Sgsubscript𝑆gS_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}} of the FRC topology (bottom red line). The ARCCC optimal topology converges much faster than the FRC topology, with the improvement being more significant at medium to lower values of U𝑈U.

The ARCCC topology has a markedly nonlinear behavior, with two asymptotes: for small U𝑈U, the sharp increasing asymptote, and the asymptotic horizontal asymptote (when all the realizable edges in ℰℰ\mathcal{E} are used.) The two meet at the knee of the curve (U=6.9×104,Sg=.555)formulae-sequence𝑈6.9superscript104subscript𝑆g.555\left(U=6.9\times 10^{4},S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}=.555\right). For U=6.9×104𝑈6.9superscript104U=6.9\times 10^{4}, the ARCCC convergence rate is Sg^=.505^subscript𝑆g.505\widehat{S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}}=.505, while FRC’s is Sg=.152subscript𝑆g.152S_{\mbox{\scriptsize{g}}}=.152, showing that ARCCC’s topology is 3.33.33.3 times faster than FRC’s. For this example, we compute Ctot=14.7×104subscript𝐶tot14.7superscript104C_{\mbox{\scriptsize{tot}}}=14.7\times 10^{4}, which shows that ARCCC’s optimal topology achieves the asymptotic performance while using less than 50 % of the communication cost.

VIII Conclusions

The paper presents the design of the topology of a sensor network to maximize the convergence rate of the consensus algorithm as a convex optimization problem. We consider that the communication channels among sensors may fail at random times, that communication among sensors incurs a cost, and that there is an overall communication cost constraint in the network. We first establish necessary and sufficient conditions for mss convergence and a.s. convergence in terms of the expected value of the algebraic connectivity of the random graph defining the network topology and in terms of the algebraic connectivity of the average topology. We apply semidefinite programming to solve numerically for the optimal topology design of the random network subject to the communication cost constraint. Because the topology is random, the solution to this optimization specifies for each realizable link its probability of error (aka, SNR), or the fraction of time the link is expected to be active. We show by a simulation study that the resulting topology design can improve by about 300 % the convergence speed of average consensus over more common designs, e.g., geometric topologies where sensors communicate with sensors within a fixed distance. Our study also shows that the optimal random topology can achieve the convergence speed of a non-random network at a fraction of the cost.

  • [32] Y. Kim and M. Mesbahi, “On maximizing the second smallest eigenvalue of a state-dependent graph Laplacian,” IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control, vol. 51, no. 1, pp. 116 – 120, Jan. 2006.
